facts: The book was reviewed in 1908.
The review summarizes the plot of the story.
The plot of the story is light.
The review is overenthusiastic.
A young New Yorker is rich.
A young New Yorker hears a woman's voice singing divinely from his window on a night of fog and mist.
The young New Yorker falls in love with the voice.
The young New Yorker falls downstairs in a hurry to see the singer.
By the time the young New Yorker reaches the street, the singer has vanished.
Only a policeman remains when the young New Yorker reaches the street.
The young New Yorker is Mr. Hillard.
Mr. Hillard meets the young, adventurous singer again under mystifying circumstances.
Mr. Hillard and the singer dine together.
The singer comes in a mask.
The scene shifts to Italy.
An American comic opera company is stranded at Venice.
The beautiful singer becomes the prima donna of the American comic opera company.
The soubrette is Kitty Killigrew.
Kitty Killigrew is involved in a subplot.
Amusing things happen at Venice.
Thrilling things happen at Monte Carlo.
The climax is reached at Florence.
The curtain goes down on happy lovers at Bellaggio.
rules: What the voice has begun, the mask puts the finishing touches to.
Mr. Hillard is full forty fathoms deep in love and curiosity.
